Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Regional trophic diversity dynamics in North American Eocene mammals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Due largely to climate change and changes in land use, at least 20% of the mammal species living today are threatened with extinction. The fossil record is a key source of information about how species responded to environmental change in the past. Fossil material from carnivorous mammals in southern California, dating to the Eocene and Oligocene epochs (56 - 23 million years ago), will be examined to learn more about the ecology of those species and how they may have been impacted by a changing environment. This material also will be compared to records from central Oregon to examine patterns of change in regional mammalian diversity at a time when there was a dramatic loss in flowering plant diversity. Together, these analyses will provide insights into the timing and magnitude of changes in mammalian diversity, and how the extent and timing of this loss of diversity compared for carnivorous and non-carnivorous mammals.
To encourage more dialogues between paleontologists and conservation biologists, and to promote the irreplaceable value of paleontological collections in biodiversity research, the findings of this study will be disseminated through professional scientific meetings, undergraduate-level college courses, and museum tours and lectures for schoolchildren and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How are the evolution and extinction of carnivorous mammals tied to those of their potential prey? Understanding the answer is important in light of the major stresses on ecosystems today and the consequent accelerated rate of extinction we are witnessing.  We addressed this question through investigation of the diversity trajectories of fossil mammals in the middle Eocene (approximately 48 to 38 million years ago) of southern California. We conducted a detailed study of fossils in the collections of ten institutions (most importantly, the San Diego Natural History Museum and the University of California Museum of Paleontology) to track the appearances and disappearances of many species of carnivorous mammals and their prey over roughly five million years.  Through this process, we discovered three new species of fossil carnivoraforms (which today include dogs, cats, and their relatives) in museum collections, contributing to increased knowledge of the diversity of carnivorous mammals during a critical early phase of their evolutionary history. Our analyses of the mammalian assemblage in southern California suggest a broad connection between the diversities of carnivores and their potential mammalian prey. At the same time, we found that the response of carnivores as measured by changes in their ecological composition (i.e., distributions body size and degree of meat consumption) does not exactly track the shifting composition of potential prey over evolutionary time, possibly because many carnivores are flexible predators but are vulnerable to habitat changes. Our findings have key implications for long-term preservation of mammalian biodiversity, namely that changes in prey species can affect their predators in complex ways, and call for additional research on ecological factors that contribute to evolution and extinction of mammalian carnivores. The discovery of new species underscores the importance of natural history museum collections for understanding the deep histories of biodiversity.
